Chief Complaint: OUTPATIENT CARDIOLOGIST:  [**Doctor Last Name 2563**]
   .
   PCP: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 252**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 75**]
   .
   .
   CHIEF COMPLAINT: weakness, ankle swelling
   24 Hour Events:
   HISTORY OF PRESENTING ILLNESS:69 yo m with hx of systolic [**Last Name (LF) 7132**], [**First Name3 (LF) 300**]
   15-20%, s/p CABG x2, s/p MVR and tricuspid valve annuloplasty ring and
   PAF for which he is on coumadin and ITP who presents with increased
   weakness and difficulty ambulating due to left ankle pain. He has had
   multiple admissions recently, one from [**3-12**]- [**3-15**] for heart failure
   exacerbation at which time he had been started on spironolactone 25
   daily and his lasix dose increased from 60 to 80, and then again
   [**2072-3-18**]  due to misinterpretation of med dosing instructions, he was
   taking two 5mg tabs daily instead of two (2.5mg) tabs. At time of dc
   his INR was 2.4 and he was dc'd on stable dose of 5mg coumadin. He was
   also noted to be hypovolemic and hypernatremic with Cr 2.1 from
   baseline 1.0-1.4 and his lasix and aldactone were initially stopped
   then restarted at 40 and 235 respectively on [**2154-3-25**].  Three days prior
   to this admission he had noted progressive dyspnea on exertion and
   weakness as well as ankle pain,as well as increased swelling in his
   ankles and abdomen, but what was most bothersome to him was his pain in
   his left ankle on ambulation which was limiting his mobility and so he
   presented to the ED on [**2154-3-29**] where he was noted to be in afib and
   volume overloaded on exam with BNP elevated to [**Numeric Identifier 11793**] from 7201 and INR
   elevated to 20 with no evidence bleeding and he was reversed with
   vitamin K. He was also found to be in acute on chronic renal failure
   with Cr 2.2 from baseline He had a CXR showing mild pulmonary vascular
   congestion with small bilateral pleural effusions and a retrocardiac
   opacity likely represents atelectasis, although underlying infection
   cannot be excluded. Foot x-ray was negative for fx with evaluation by
   ortho with diagnosis of cellulitis with hematoma for which he was
   started on vanc/ceftaz. EKG showed atrial fibrillation at 98 bpm with
   LVH, intraventricular conduction delay and overall no changes from
   prior.
   .
   He was diuresed with lasix IV 20 in ED and  then continued to receive
   IV boluses on [**Hospital1 2259**] and was diuresed with lasix boluses (40mg IV BID)
   then subsequently changed to lasix drip yesterday, limited by systolic
   bp's 80-90s with his baseline around 90 with I/O even unable to get
   negative. His Cr was also creeping up, from and eventually started on
   milrinone drip on the floor and subsequently transfered to the ICU for
   ionotrope assisted diuresis.
   He had been on lisinopril 5 as o/p which was titrated down over course
   of weekend and dc'd on day of ICU admission.
   His INR was 1.8 after being reversed with vit K and was started on
   heparin bridge, but on day of ICU transfer he was noteed to have nose
   bleed and INR at 2.6 so hep dc'd.
   On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep
   venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery,
   myalgias, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. he denies
   recent fevers, chills or rigors. S/he denies exertional buttock or calf
   pain. All of the other review of systems were negative.
   .
   Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain,
   paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea,  palpitations, syncope or
   presyncope.
   .
   [**2154-4-1**]: Echo
   2D-ECHOCARDIOGRAM:  The left atrium is moderately dilated. No left
   atrial mass/thrombus seen (best excluded by transesophageal
   echocardiography). The right atrial pressure is indeterminate. Left
   ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity is
   moderately dilated with severe global hypokinesis. The basal inferior
   and inferolateral wall is hypokinetic but moves best, the remaining
   segments are near akinetic (LVEF <20 %). The estimated cardiac index is
   depressed (<2.0L/min/m2). No masses or thrombi are seen in the left
   ventricle. The right ventricular cavity is markedly dilated with severe
   global free wall hypokinesis. The diameters of aorta at the sinus,
   ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are
   mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic
   regurgitation is seen. A bioprosthetic mitral valve prosthesis is
   present. The mitral prosthesis appears well seated, with normal leaflet
   motion and transvalvular gradients. No mitral regurgitation is seen.
   [Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation may be
   significantly UNDERestimated.] The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly
   thickened. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There
   is no pericardial effusion.
   Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2152-12-26**], the
   estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is now lower.
   Biventricular cavity size is now increased with similar systolic
   function.
   CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS:
   The left ventricular ejection fraction is <40%, a threshold for which
   the patient may benefit from a beta blocker and an ACE inhibotor or
   [**Last Name (un) 239**].
   .
   Echo ([**2153-9-5**]): The left atrium is markedly dilated. The right atrium
   is moderately dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular
   hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. There is
   severe global left ventricular hypokinesis (LVEF = 15-20%). The
   estimated cardiac index is depressed (<2.0L/min/m2). The right
   ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with moderate global free wall
   hypokinesis. There is abnormal septal motion/position consistent with
   right ventricular pressure/volume overload. The aortic valve leaflets
   (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace
   aortic regurgitation is seen. A bioprosthetic mitral valve prosthesis
   is present. The mitral prosthesis appears well seated, with normal
   leaflet motion and transvalvular gradients. No mitral regurgitation is
   seen. [Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation
   may be significantly UNDERestimated.] A tricuspid valve annuloplasty
   ring is present. The tricuspid annuloplasty ring appears well seated
   and is not obstructing flow. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is
   seen. There is severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is
   no pericardial effusion.
   .
   IMPRESSION: Severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction. Dilated right
   ventricle with moderate systolic dysfunction and evidence of
   pressure/volume overload. Normally-functioning mitral valve
   bioprosthesis. Tricuspid valve annuloplasty ring with moderate residual
   central regurgitation. Severe pulmonary hypertension.
   Holter [**2153-8-28**]: aPBs
   CARDIAC CATH: [**2151-10-12**]:
   1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system
   demonstrated severe native 3-vessel disease. The LMCA was 90% occluded.
   The LAD was totally occluded proximally; the distal LAD filled via a
   patent LIMA graft. The LCX was totally occluded proximally; OM1 filled
   via an SVG; the sequential graft from OM1 to OM2 was occluded, but
   OM2 filled via a robust epicardial collateral. The RCA was totally
   occluded proximally; the distal vessel filled via left-to-right
   collaterals from the grafted LAD.
   2. Selective graft angiography showed a patent SVG to OM1; the jump
   segment to OM2 was occluded, but OM2 filled via an epicardial
   collateral. The SVG to RPDA was totally occulded. The LIMA to LAD was
   widely patent.
   3. Resting hemodynamics revealed markedly elevated biventricular
   filling
   pressures with moderate pulmonary hypertension and reduced cardiac
   index. There were large V-waves on the RA tracing consistent with
   severe
   tricuspid regurgitation.
   4. Aortography showed a heavily calcified ascending aorta.
   FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
   1. Three vessel coronary artery disease.
   2. Severe mitral regurgitation.
   3. Severe tricuspid regurgitation.
   4. LV systolic and diastolic dysfunction.
   Past Medical History:
   -Hypertension
   -Coronary Artery Disease, [**2128**] CABG LIMA to LAD, SVG to rPDA and SVG
   sequential graft to OM1 and OM2; [**2151**] CABG SVG to rPDA
   -Chronic systolic CHF EF 15-20%
   -Severe tricuspid regurgitation s/p Tricuspid valve annuloplasty ring
   [**2151**]
   -Severe mitral regurgitation s/p porcine MVR [**2151**]
   -Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation on coumadin, s/p cardioversion [**9-2**],
   h/o bradycardia with beta blocker
   -PAD s/p bilateral carotid endarterectomy
   -ITP
   -Pancreatic cysts (likely IPMN)
   -h/o cholestatic jaundice in [**2151**] (thought secondary to drug reaction,
   since resolved, had 2 liver biopsies)
   .
   Allergies: Ambien / Beta-Blockers (Beta-Adrenergic Blocking Agts)
   .
   MEDICATIONS:
   1. Nitroglycerin 0.3 mg Tablet, SL PRN
   2. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet QD
   3. Atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet P.O qhs
   4. Calcium  Oral
   5. Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 400 unit daily
   6. Warfarin 5 mg Tablet daily
   7. Lasix 40 mg PO daily
   8. Aldactone 25 mg PO
   Social History:
   Divorced. Lives alone. 2 children. Tries to follow 2g Na diet
   with 50 ounce fluid restriction. Lives alone. He is retired.
   Former ETOH abuse [**2150**] and denies current ETOH use and denies
   illicit drug use.
   Family History:
   Mother with hyperlipidemia and died of coronary artery disease
   in her 60s. There is no family history of premature coronary
   artery disease or sudden death.
   Allergies:
   Ambien (Oral) (Zolpidem Tartrate)
   Confusion/Delir
   Beta-Blockers (Beta-Adrenergic Blocking Agts)
   Very sensitive
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Furosemide (Lasix) - 10 mg/hour
   Other ICU medications:
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below

   Vitals: T:  97.4 BP:103/43 HR:69  RR:16  O2 sat:96%  RA
   General: Alert, oriented, no acute distress
   HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear
   Neck: supple, JVP elevated to ear, no LAD
   Lungs: Clear to ausculatation bilaterally. No w/r/c.
   CV: Irregular rhythm. Normal rate. normal S1 + S2, loud systolic
   murmur at LLSB.
   Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present,
   no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly
   Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, 2+ peripheral edema to the knee
   bilterally. Erythema over left shin/ankle with tenderness to palpation.
   Compression stockings bilaterally.
   Labs / Radiology
        [image002.jpg]
   Assessment and Plan
   Summary: 69 yo m with hx of [**Year (2 digits) 7132**], MVR, and Tricuspid ring, PAF,
   admitted to [**Hospital1 2259**] with elevated INR and acute exacerbation of systolic
   heart failure with lasix driven diuresis limited by persistent
   hypotension, admitted to CCU for ionotrope assisted diuresis.
   .
   Assessment and Plan:
   .
   # Acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure: The patient presents
   with fluid overload, especially in the lower extremities. He has been
   compliant with his lasix and aldactone. He noticed his legs swelling,
   but he said his weight hasn't increased. He has been keeping to his
   fluid restriction. Notes that he has eaten soup with low sodium over
   the past couple of days, so salt intact can be a precipitant. Has low
   LVEF of 15-20% on last echo. On his last hospital discharge, his weight
   was 164.6 pounds. BNP elevated to [**Numeric Identifier 11793**] (last one: 7201).
   -Lasix IV PRN
   -strict I&Os, daily weight
   -dietary intact teaching
   -cannot be on beta blocker since symptomatic bradycardia
   .
   # Coagulopathy/microcytic anemia: INR supratherapeutic to 20 on
   admission, now 2.6 following reversal with vit K. Was being bridged to
   coumadin with hep GTT. However INR today 2.6. Goal reported 2.5-3.5
   although pt has bioprosthetic valve, and afib.Also has nose bleeding
   this am which has stopped. HCT 36.1 with MCV 81 on admission, 35y/d 31
   today.
   -d/c heparin GTT.
   -continue coumadin 2.5 for now.
   -holding ASA
   -[**Hospital1 **] crit checks
   -Guiac all stools
   -active type and screen
   -iron/hemolysis labs>? *****
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient presented with a
   creatinine of 2.2. His new baseline since [**3-20**] has been 2.0-2.2 from
   1.2 previously. Was on aldactone 25 and Lasix 40 mg PO at home which
   was held from [**3-20**] to [**3-25**]. Thought to be ATN in setting of lasix use
   but also had hyaline casts on UA suggesting prerenal compontent
   -check urine lytes
   -strict I&Os, avoid nephrotoxins
   -hold aldactone
   .
   # Bioprosthetic mitral valve: The patient has a bioprosthetic mitral
   valve and need anticoagulation
   -INR wnl,  Goal INR: 2.0-3
   # Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation: Patient currently in atrial
   fibrillation, unsure if playing a role in his exacerbation of heart
   failure, HR currently wnl
   -Continue to monitor on telemetry
   -continue to hold metoprolol given hypotension
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Likely due to low intravascular volume , CHF appears
   hypervolemic on exam.
   -previously in 130s, 126 on admission, now 121. Asymptomatic.
   Continue to trend.
   .
   # Hypertension: currently hyotensive.
   -holding lisinopril, metoprolol for now
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue home atorvastatin
   .
   # Diet: Low salt, cardiac heart healthy
   .
   # PIV: PICC, 20 guage.
   .
   # Code status: full code, confirmed
   .
   # Dispo: floor for now
   .
   .
   .
   [**Doctor First Name 11738**] [**Doctor Last Name 11739**]
   Internal Medicine, [**Pager number 11740**]
   ---------------------------------------------------------------------
   [**Hospital1 2259**] B Progress Note, [**4-1**]
   .
   S: Patient still very weak. Has pain in the left leg when puts weight
   on it. No nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, fevers, chills,
   headache, back ache, melena, BRBPR.
   .
   O:
   Admission Physical Exam:
   Vitals: T: 98.1, BP: 83/44 (80-95)/(46-78), HR: 83, RR: 20, O2 sat:
   100% RA
   Admission weight: 74.2 kg
   General: Alert, oriented, no acute distress
   HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear
   Neck: supple, JVP elevated to ear, no LAD
   Lungs: Clear to ausculatation bilaterally. No w/r/c.
   CV: Irregular rhythm. Normal rate. normal S1 + S2, loud systolic
   murmur at LLSB.
   Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present,
   no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly
   Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, 2+ peripheral edema to the knee
   bilterally. Brusing on left shin with tenderness to palpation. Cool
   left foot, 1+ DP/PT pulses Sensation intact. Able to wiggle toes on
   left
   .
   Assessment and Plan:
   .
   #Acute exacerbation of stystolic heart failure: admitted with evidence
   volume overload worsened in setting possible dieterary salt load, with
   pt compliant with lasix/aldactone therapy and fluid restriction. Unable
   on floor to diuresis with lasix bolus/drip given persistent
   asymptomatic hypotension.
   Continue lasix drip with goal urine output 100cc/hr, weaning as
   tolerated. If  unable to achieve, add milrinone to maintain BP while
   uptitrating diuretic. If hypotension with milrinone can start low dose
   phenylephrine. Lisinopril restarted on admission, down titrated and
   dc'd today due to hypotension.
   -continue lasix drip 5-15mg/kg/hr
   -daily weights, strict I/O goal neg 1L/day.
   -fluid restrict <1L/day
   Hold  holding BB given asymptomatic bradycardia
   -restart lisinopril if Cr/K tolerates for afterload reduction.
   -pt does not desire ICD.
   .
   # LLE cellulitis. Being followed by ortho. On ancef (started [**3-31**]) and
   elevation.
   continue ancef
   Can weight bear.
   f/u ortho recs
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient presented with a
   creatinine of 2.2, higher than his baseline of 1.2. Currently at Cr of
   2.2. Likely ATN in the setting of lasix use and/or pre-renal if low EF
   (forward flow).
   -send urine lytes
   -strict I&Os, avoid nephrotoxins
   -trend Cr
   .
   # Transaminitis on admission likely due to hepatic congestion, no RUQ
   tenderness or epigastric discomfort. Trending down from ALT/AST 80s to
   -Continue to trend LFTs
   # Hyperkalemia: Might be due to lisinopril, renal failure.
   -Continue lasix gtt
   -PM lytes
   .
   # Transaminitis: likely due to hepatic congestion, no RUQ tenderness or
   epigastric discomfort.
   -Continue to trend LFTs
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: low sodium, heart healthy diet
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2154-4-1**] 03:00 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2154-4-1**] 03:28 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: coumadin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Patient
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU for now.

Based on the provided medical record, the patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, mitral valve replacement, tricuspid valve annuloplasty, and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the hospital with a supratherapeutic international normalized ratio (INR) and acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure with fluid overload.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an estimated ejection fraction of 15-20%.
2. Severe tricuspid regurgitation with a moderate residual central regurgitation.
3. Severe pulmonary hypertension.
4. Chronic renal failure with a creatinine of 2.2, higher than his baseline of 1.2.
5. Acute on chronic renal failure with a possible diagnosis of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) in the setting of lasix use and/or pre-renal failure.
6. Hyponatremia with a sodium level of 121 mmol/L, likely due to low intravascular volume and CHF.
7. Hypertension, currently asymptomatic.
8. Hyperlipidemia, being treated with atorvastatin.
9. LLE cellulitis, being followed by orthopedics.
10. Transaminitis, likely due to hepatic congestion, with trending down from ALT/AST 80s.

The patient is currently receiving treatment for his conditions, including:

1. Lasix drip for diuresis and fluid management.
2. Milrinone for ionotrope-assisted diuresis and blood pressure support.
3. Coumadin for anticoagulation.
4. Heparin bridge for anticoagulation.
5. Aldactone for fluid management.
6. Lisinopril for afterload reduction, held due to hypotension.
7. Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.
8. Ancef for LLE cellulitis.
9. Strict I/Os and fluid restriction to manage fluid overload.
10. Close monitoring of laboratory values, including creatinine, potassium, and liver function tests.

The patient's current medications include:

1. Nitroglycerin 0.3 mg SL PRN.
2. Aspirin 81 mg PO QD.
3. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QHS.
4. Calcium oral.
5. Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 400 IU daily.
6. Warfarin 5 mg PO daily.
7. Lasix 40 mg PO daily.
8. Aldactone 25 mg PO.

The patient's family history is significant for coronary artery disease in his mother, who died in her 60s.

The patient's social history is significant for former ethanol abuse and a history of smoking.

The patient's physical examination is significant for:

1. Weakness and pain in the left leg.
2. Erythema and tenderness over the left shin.
3. Bruising and tenderness over the left ankle.
4. Cool left foot with 1+ DP/PT pulses.
5. Sensation intact in the left foot.

The patient's vital signs are:

1. Temperature: 98.1°F.
2. Blood pressure: 83/44 mmHg.
3. Heart rate: 83 beats per minute.
4. Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute.
5. Oxygen saturation: 100% on room air.

The patient's laboratory values are:

1. Creatinine: 2.2 mg/dL.
2. Potassium: 4.5 mmol/L.
3. Sodium: 121 mmol/L.
4. ALT: 80 IU/L.
5. AST: 80 IU/L.

The patient's diagnosis is acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure with fluid overload, severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction, severe tricuspid regurgitation, and chronic renal failure. The patient requires close monitoring and management of his fluid status, electrolytes, and medications to prevent further complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his medical conditions to prevent complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient is a 67-inch tall individual with a weight-bearing left lower extremity cellulitis, acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, and acute on chronic renal failure. They have been admitted with evidence of volume overload, worsened by possible dietary salt load, and are currently on a lasix drip for diuresis. The patient's blood pressure is in the 90s systolic, and they have asymptomatic hypotension.

The patient has been diagnosed with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, cellulitis, and acute on chronic renal failure. They are being treated with lasix drip, milrinone, and phenylephrine to maintain blood pressure and diuresis. Lisinopril has been restarted, but at a lower dose due to hypotension. The patient's creatinine has improved from 2.2 to 1.7, and their potassium level is 4.8 mg/dL.

The patient has also been diagnosed with transaminitis, likely due to hepatic congestion, and is being treated with close monitoring of liver function tests. They have hyperkalemia, which may be due to lisinopril and renal failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's systolic heart failure is acute on chronic, and further worsening of cardiac function can lead to decreased cardiac output and decreased perfusion of vital organs.
2. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may worsen if they continue to experience volume overload, hypotension, or nephrotoxins.
3. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level of 4.8 mg/dL is high, and further worsening of hyperkalemia can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
4. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis may worsen if they continue to experience hepatic congestion or if they develop other liver insults.
5. Cellulitis: The patient's left lower extremity cellulitis may worsen if they do not receive adequate treatment, leading to increased risk of sepsis and organ dysfunction.
6. Blood pressure instability: The patient's asymptomatic hypotension may worsen if they continue to receive beta-blockers, leading to decreased cardiac output and decreased perfusion of vital organs.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing infections, particularly in the setting of immunosuppression and central venous catheters.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of their cardiac, renal, and hepatic function, as well as treatment of their cellulitis and hyperkalemia.

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, cellulitis of the left lower extremity, acute on chronic renal failure, transaminitis, and hyperkalemia. The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure and is currently on lasix and aldactone therapy with fluid restriction. He was started on a lasix drip and milrinone was added to maintain blood pressure while uptitrating diuretic. The patient's creatinine level has improved from 2.2 to 1.7, but his potassium level remains elevated at 4.8.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of heart failure: The patient's systolic heart failure is not well-controlled, and his creatinine level is still elevated, which may indicate ongoing volume overload.
2. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may progress to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease if not managed properly.
3. Cellulitis: The patient's cellulitis of the left lower extremity may spread or worsen if not treated aggressively with antibiotics and proper wound care.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's elevated potassium level may lead to cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest if not managed properly with potassium-lowering medications and close monitoring.
5. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis may worsen if not managed properly with liver function tests and potential treatment with antiviral medications.
6. Blood pressure instability: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and he may require close monitoring and adjustments to his medications to maintain a stable blood pressure.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload may worsen if not managed properly with diuretics and fluid restriction.
8. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his immunocompromised state and presence of central lines and other invasive devices.
9. Sepsis: The patient may develop sepsis if his infection is not managed properly or if he develops a secondary infection.
10. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen or convert to a more serious arrhythmia if not managed properly with anticoagulation therapy and close monitoring.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-inch tall individual who has been admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with a bioprosthetic valve and ring, and has been taking Coumadin 2.5 mg/day.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C (97°F), a heart rate of 82 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 98/46 mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.

The patient's physical examination is notable for a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, which radiates to the carotids. The patient's abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended, with bowel sounds present. The patient's extremities are warm and well-perfused, with 1+ pulses.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 4.7 x 10^9/L, a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL, and a platelet count of 123 x 10^9/L. The patient's creatinine level has improved to 1.6 mg/dL, and his potassium level is 4.3 mmol/L.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure: The patient is to continue with a lasix drip at 15 mg/hour, with a goal diuresis of >1 L. The patient is to be monitored for asymptomatic hypotension.
* LLE cellulitis: The patient is to continue with ancef (started on [**3-31**]) and elevation.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient is to have his creatinine level trended.
* Transaminitis: The patient is to have his liver function tests trended.
* Afib/MVR with bioprosthetic valve/ring: The patient is to restart on a dose of Coumadin 2.5 mg/day, and resume home dose of 5 mg Coumadin today.
* Hyperkalemia: The patient is to continue with lasix gtt and [**Hospital1 **] lytes.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of heart failure: The patient's systolic heart failure may worsen if the patient does not respond to treatment or if the patient experiences a decline in cardiac function.
* Cellulitis: The patient's LLE cellulitis may worsen if the patient does not receive appropriate treatment or if the patient develops an infection.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may worsen if the patient does not receive appropriate treatment or if the patient experiences a decline in renal function.
* Liver failure: The patient's transaminitis may worsen if the patient does not receive appropriate treatment or if the patient experiences a decline in liver function.
* Stroke: The patient's atrial fibrillation may increase the risk of stroke if the patient does not receive appropriate treatment or if the patient experiences a decline in cardiac function.
* Ventricular arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation may increase the risk of ventricular arrhythmias if the patient does not receive appropriate treatment or if the patient experiences a decline in cardiac function.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but the patient is at risk for worsening of their heart failure, cellulitis, renal failure, liver failure, stroke, and ventricular arrhythmias.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, chronic kidney disease, and cellulitis. He has a history of atrial fibrillation, mitral valve replacement with a bioprosthetic valve, and is taking medications for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and heart failure. The patient is currently on a furosemide drip for volume overload and is being managed with a low-sodium diet and fluid restriction.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure in the low 90s and a heart rate of 82 beats per minute. His oxygen saturation is 98% on room air, and he is not requiring respiratory support. His physical examination is notable for a loud systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, which radiates to the carotids.

The patient's laboratory results show improvements in his liver function tests, with decreased levels of alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase. His creatinine level has decreased from 2.2 to 1.6, and his potassium level is 4.3 mmol/L.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level has decreased, but he may still be at risk for AKI due to his pre-existing chronic kidney disease and the use of furosemide.
2. Heart Failure: The patient's systolic heart failure is being managed with furosemide and a low-sodium diet, but he may still be at risk for further decompensation.
3. Cellulitis: The patient's cellulitis is being treated with antibiotics, but he may still be at risk for complications such as sepsis or abscess formation.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is 4.3 mmol/L, which may be due to his kidney disease and the use of lisinopril. He may be at risk for further hyperkalemia if his kidney function deteriorates.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is 123,000/mL, which may be due to his liver disease or kidney disease. He may be at risk for bleeding if his platelet count decreases further.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is being managed with warfarin, but he may still be at risk for further episodes of atrial fibrillation.
7. Mitral Valve Disease: The patient's mitral valve replacement with a bioprosthetic valve may be at risk for further complications such as valve failure or endocarditis.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 56-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, chronic kidney disease, and cellulitis. The patient has been receiving lasix drip at 15 mg/hour and has demonstrated a net negative fluid balance of 1.5 L over the past 24 hours, with a stable blood pressure in the low 90s. The patient's laboratory results show an improvement in creatinine levels, from 2.2 to 1.6, and a trend towards decreasing transaminase levels.

The patient's physical examination reveals a warm and well-perfused extremities, with 1+ pulses and stable peripheral edema. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 98% on room air. The patient's cardiac status is stable, with a normal sinus rhythm and a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Further worsening of heart failure: The patient's net negative fluid balance and stable blood pressure may indicate a potential for further worsening of heart failure.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels have improved, but the patient's chronic kidney disease and potential for acute tubular necrosis may still pose a risk for further worsening of renal function.
3. Cellulitis: The patient's cellulitis may worsen if not properly treated, leading to further complications such as sepsis or amputation.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium levels are slightly elevated, which may be due to lisinopril, renal failure, or other factors.
5. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminase levels are trending down, but the patient's liver function may still be compromised, leading to further complications such as hepatic encephalopathy.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continued lasix drip at 15 mg/hour to achieve a goal diuresis of greater than 1 L.
2. Close monitoring of the patient's fluid balance and blood pressure.
3. Trending of creatinine levels to monitor for further worsening of renal function.
4. Continued treatment of cellulitis with antibiotics and elevation.
5. Monitoring of potassium levels to prevent further hyperkalemia.
6. Trending of transaminase levels to monitor for further liver damage.
7. Restarting of Coumadin therapy to achieve a goal INR of 2.3.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, chronic kidney disease, and cellulitis. He has a history of severe asymptomatic bradycardia and is currently on lasix drip for volume overload. His laboratory results show worsening renal function, hyperkalemia, and transaminitis. He is being treated with lasix, aldactone, and lisinopril, and is being followed by orthopedics for his cellulitis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's systolic heart failure is exacerbated by volume overload, and the lasix drip is not effectively diuresing him. This may lead to further worsening of his cardiac condition.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, and he has a history of chronic kidney disease. This may lead to further decline in his renal function.
3. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium levels are elevated, which may lead to cardiac arrhythmias or even cardiac arrest if not treated.
4. Cellulitis: The patient has a cellulitis infection that is not fully treated, which may lead to further complications such as sepsis or abscess formation.
5. Transaminitis: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, which may indicate liver damage or congestion. This may lead to further complications such as coagulopathy or hepatic encephalopathy.
6. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which may lead to inadequate perfusion of vital organs and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Bradycardia: The patient has a history of severe asymptomatic bradycardia, which may worsen with the administration of beta-blockers or other medications that slow the heart rate.
8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient is on a low-sodium, heart-healthy diet, which may lead to nutritional deficiencies if not properly monitored and managed.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for further complications and requires close monitoring and management by the ICU team to prevent or mitigate these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-inch tall individual who is alert, oriented, and has no acute distress. They have a history of chronic heart failure (CHF) and have developed acute-on-chronic CHF, which is characterized by decreased cardiac output, increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, and decreased left ventricular ejection fraction.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C (97.9°F), heart rate of 82 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure of 98/46 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. Their hemodynamic monitoring shows a sinus rhythm with a normal heart rate and rhythm.

The patient's laboratory results show stable kidney function, with a creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 29 mg/dL. Their liver function tests (LFTs) show improved liver function, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 48 units/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 92 units/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for a history of cellulitis, which is characterized by inflammation and infection of the skin and underlying tissues. They have also had a history of beta-blocker sensitivity, which is a contraindication for the use of beta-blockers.

The patient's current medications include furosemide (Lasix) 15 mg/hour, which is used to treat edema and hypertension. They also have a PICC line in place, which is used for intravenous medication administration.

The patient's assessment and plan include the following:

* AEROBIC CAPACITY / ENDURANCE, IMPAIRED
* GAIT, IMPAIRED
* TRANSFERS, IMPAIRED
* HEART FAILURE (CHF), SYSTOLIC, ACUTE ON CHRONIC
* CELLULITIS

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Worsening of heart failure, leading to increased fluid accumulation and decreased cardiac output
* Development of respiratory failure, leading to increased respiratory rate and decreased oxygen saturation
* Increased risk of infection, particularly in the skin and underlying tissues
* Development of electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia
* Increased risk of bleeding, particularly due to the use of anticoagulant medications

In conclusion, the patient is a 67-inch tall individual who is alert, oriented, and has no acute distress. They have a history of chronic heart failure (CHF) and have developed acute-on-chronic CHF. They have stable vital signs and laboratory results, but are at risk for worsening of heart failure, respiratory failure, infection, electrolyte imbalances, and bleeding.

The patient is a 67-inch tall individual with a weight not specified, admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute on chronic systolic heart failure, cellulitis, and impaired aerobic capacity, endurance, gait, and transfers. They have been receiving various medications, including furosemide and antibiotics. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C (97.9°F), heart rate of 82 bpm, blood pressure of 98/46 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 inspirations per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy, but not mechanically ventilated.

The patient's laboratory results show stable hemoglobin and platelet counts, but decreased creatinine levels, indicating improved kidney function. The patient's liver function tests have improved, with decreased ALT and AST levels. The patient's calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus levels are within normal ranges.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's systolic heart failure may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to decreased cardiac output, increased mortality, and prolonged hospital stay.
2. Infection: The patient's cellulitis and potential bacterial colonization of the PICC line and other invasive devices may lead to sepsis, septic shock, and increased morbidity and mortality.
3. Kidney injury: The patient's decreased creatinine levels may be a sign of acute kidney injury, which could worsen if not addressed promptly, leading to increased mortality and morbidity.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's impaired aerobic capacity and endurance may increase the risk of respiratory failure, particularly if the patient develops pneumonia or other respiratory complications.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's impaired nutritional status may lead to decreased muscle mass, weakness, and increased risk of complications, such as pressure ulcers and respiratory failure.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose levels may fluctuate, increasing the risk of hyperglycemia, which could lead to complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar nonketotic coma, and increased mortality.
7. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count may decrease, increasing the risk of bleeding, particularly if the patient receives anticoagulant therapy or undergoes invasive procedures.
8. Central nervous system complications: The patient's impaired cognitive function may increase the risk of central nervous system complications, such as seizures, stroke, and increased intracranial pressure.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of their current condition and potential medical complications:

The patient is a 67-inch tall, 72.5 kg male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, chronic on acute, and possible cellulitis of the left lower extremity. They have a history of atrial fibrillation with a bioprosthetic valve and ring, and are currently in sinus rhythm.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 100/61 mmHg. They are receiving furosemide (Lasix) at 15 mg/hour to manage their heart failure, and their fluid balance is being closely monitored.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 10.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 123 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.6 mg/dL
* Glucose: 118 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: potassium 4.3 mEq/L, magnesium 1.9 mg/dL, and phosphorus 3.3 mg/dL

The patient's medical complications include:

* Acute on chronic renal failure, likely due to lasix use and/or pre-renal factors
* Hyperkalemia, possibly due to lisinopril and renal failure
* Transaminitis, likely due to hepatic congestion
* Cellulitis of the left lower extremity

The patient's plan includes:

* Continued diuresis with lasix drip to manage heart failure
* Monitoring of fluid balance and electrolyte levels
* Hold on lisinopril due to asymptomatic bradycardia
* Continued fluid restriction to <2L/day
* Monitoring of creatinine levels to trend
* Continued treatment of cellulitis with antibiotics and elevation
* Restarted Coumadin dose at 2.5 mg/day to manage atrial fibrillation

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Worsening of heart failure and pulmonary edema
* Development of respiratory failure
* Increased risk of bleeding due to Coumadin therapy
* Progression of cellulitis to sepsis
* Further decline in renal function
* Development of arrhythmias due to atrial fibrillation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-inch tall, 72.5 kg individual with a history of atrial fibrillation, chronic heart failure, and cellulitis. The patient was admitted to the ICU due to an acute exacerbation of heart failure.

Over the past 24 hours, the patient's vital signs have remained stable, with a temperature range of 36.2-36.6°C, heart rate of 83-91 bpm, blood pressure of 100-111/59-62 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 18-21 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation remains at 100%.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, with a range of 4.3-4.7 K/uL. The hemoglobin level is 10.4 g/dL, and the platelet count is 109-123 K/uL. The patient's creatinine level is 1.6-2.0 mg/dL, and the glucose level is 90-118 mg/dL.

The patient's physical examination reveals clear lungs, a stable murmur, and 1+ pitting edema. The patient has a temperature of 36.2°C, and the extremities are warm and well-perfused.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening of heart failure: The patient's condition is already compromised, and any further decline in cardiac function can lead to increased morbidity and mortality.
2. Infection: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may indicate an underlying infection. Failure to identify and treat the infection can lead to sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, which increases the risk of bleeding. Any invasive procedures or interventions should be performed with caution.
4. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, which may indicate renal insufficiency. This can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and decreased clearance of medications.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose level is elevated, which may indicate insulin resistance or inadequate insulin therapy. This can lead to hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome or diabetic ketoacidosis.
6. Thrombosis: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and chronic heart failure increases the risk of thrombosis. Anticoagulation therapy should be continued to prevent thrombus formation.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's nutritional status is impaired, which can lead to decreased immune function, muscle wasting, and increased risk of infections.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-inch tall, 72.5 kg male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, cellulitis, acute on chronic renal failure, and transaminitis. He has a history of atrial fibrillation, mitral valve replacement with a bioprosthetic valve, and is currently in sinus rhythm. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 83 bpm, blood pressure of 100/61 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. He is receiving furosemide infusion and has a fluid balance of -2057 mL over the past 24 hours.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's systolic heart failure is acute on chronic, and his fluid balance is negative, which may indicate ongoing volume overload. This could lead to further decompensation and decreased cardiac output.
2. Cellulitis progression: The patient has cellulitis in his left mid shin, which may spread if not properly managed. This could lead to increased risk of sepsis and organ failure.
3. Renal failure progression: The patient's creatinine level has improved from 2.2 to 1.6, but he still has acute on chronic renal failure. If not managed properly, this could lead to further decline in renal function and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is 4.3 mmol/L, which is above the normal range. If not managed properly, this could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Thromboembolic complications: The patient is at risk for thromboembolic complications due to his atrial fibrillation and mitral valve replacement. He is receiving anticoagulation therapy with Coumadin, but this may not be sufficient to prevent thromboembolic events.
6. Infection: The patient has a PICC line and is at risk for infection. He also has a history of cellulitis, which could increase his risk of developing sepsis.
7. Malnutrition: The patient is receiving a low-sodium, heart-healthy diet, but his nutritional status is not well-documented. He may be at risk for malnutrition, which could impact his recovery.
8. Glycemic control: The patient's glucose level is 118 mg/dL, which is above the normal range. He may be at risk for developing hyperglycemia, which could increase his risk of complications.

Overall, the patient is at risk for several medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent these complications and ensure his recovery.

The patient's laboratory results show improved creatinine levels, which is likely due to the diuretic therapy and fluid restriction. However, the patient still has elevated potassium levels, which may be related to the lisinopril medication.

The patient's physical examination reveals clear lungs, a stable murmur, and 1+ pitting edema. They have a stable atrial fibrillation rhythm, and their blood pressure is being closely monitored.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's systolic heart failure may worsen if they do not comply with their diuretic therapy and fluid restriction.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate if they develop pneumonia or other respiratory complications.
3. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels may continue to rise if they do not receive adequate diuretic therapy and fluid restriction.
4. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's potassium levels may continue to rise if they do not receive adequate treatment for hyperkalemia.
5. Infection: The patient's cellulitis and possible sepsis may worsen if they do not receive adequate antibiotic therapy and wound care.

The patient's plan of care includes continued aggressive diuresis with Lasix, fluid restriction, and close monitoring of their vital signs and laboratory results. The patient's medication regimen will be adjusted as needed to manage their heart failure, hyperkalemia, and other medical conditions.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple comorbidities and potential medical complications. Further management and monitoring are necessary to prevent and manage these complications and ensure the patient's optimal outcome.

Summary:

The patient, a 69-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU with a history of systolic heart failure, mitral valve replacement, and tricuspid ring, as well as atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the hospital with an elevated INR and acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure with lasix-driven diuresis limited by persistent hypotension. The patient is currently receiving ionotrope-assisted diuresis in the ICU.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure of 96/48 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 100% on room air, and he is receiving lasix infusion at a rate of 15 mg/hour.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 4.7 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 9.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 123 x 10^9/L. His electrolyte levels are within normal range, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.0 mEq/L. His blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels are elevated, and his glucose level is within normal range.

Potential medical complications:

1. Volume overload: The patient is receiving lasix infusion, which may lead to volume overload if not closely monitored.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 96/48 mmHg, which may indicate hypotension. This may be exacerbated by the patient's underlying heart failure and vasodilator therapy.
3. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's potassium level is slightly elevated, which may require close monitoring and potential correction.
4. Renal insufficiency: The patient's blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels are elevated, which may indicate renal insufficiency. This may require close monitoring and potential adjustment of diuretic therapy.
5. Infection: The patient's white blood cell count is slightly elevated, which may indicate an underlying infection. This may require further evaluation and potential antibiotic therapy.
6. Bleeding risk: The patient is receiving anticoagulant therapy with Coumadin, which may increase the risk of bleeding. This may require close monitoring and potential adjustment of anticoagulant therapy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Volume overload: The patient's persistent hypotension and increasing weight may indicate ongoing volume overload, which could worsen his systolic heart failure and lead to further decompensation.
2. Cellulitis: The patient's left lower extremity cellulitis may progress and lead to sepsis or other complications if not properly treated.
3. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and his acute kidney injury may worsen if not properly managed.
4. Hepatic congestion: The patient's transaminitis may be related to hepatic congestion, which could worsen if not properly managed.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to further decompensation of his heart failure and increase his risk of stroke or thromboembolism if not properly managed.
6. Blood pressure instability: The patient's persistent hypotension may lead to further decompensation of his heart failure and increase his risk of organ failure if not properly managed.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, mitral valve replacement, and tricuspid ring, admitted with an acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure. He was transferred to the ICU for ionotrope-assisted diuresis due to persistent hypotension. The patient is currently receiving lasix drips and has a goal of at least 1 L negative fluid balance each day. He has a cellulitis in the left lower extremity and is being treated with antibiotics. His anemia is being monitored, and his creatinine level has improved from 2.2 to 1.4.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure: The patient's condition can worsen if he does not achieve the goal of at least 1 L negative fluid balance each day, leading to further volume overload and decreased cardiac function.
2. Cellulitis in the left lower extremity: The patient's cellulitis can progress to a more severe infection, leading to sepsis and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen if not properly managed, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues and organs.
4. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine level may continue to rise if his kidney function does not improve, leading to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
5. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis can worsen if not properly managed, leading to liver damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Atrial fibrillation with mitral valve replacement and tricuspid ring: The patient's arrhythmia can worsen if not properly managed, leading to decreased cardiac function and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can worsen if not properly managed, leading to decreased organ perfusion and potentially life-threatening complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue lasix drips and monitor the patient's fluid balance and weight daily.
2. Monitor the patient's cellulitis and adjust antibiotic therapy as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust transfusion therapy as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's creatinine level and adjust diuretic therapy as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's transaminitis and adjust liver function tests as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and adjust antiarrhythmic therapy as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's hypotension and adjust vasopressor therapy as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of systolic heart failure, mitral valve replacement, and tricuspid ring, as well as atrial fibrillation. He was admitted with an acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, volume overload, and possible dietary salt load. The patient has been tolerating the lasix drip at 15mg/hour, with a goal diuresis of >1L, and has been maintaining a low BP in the 90s.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated creatinine (2.2) and potassium (4.3) levels, indicating acute on chronic renal failure and hyperkalemia, respectively. His liver function tests (LFTs) are trending down, and his international normalized ratio (INR) is 2.6.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to his inability to move or assess his peripheral pulses, skin, and neurologic status. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 84bpm, blood pressure of 96/48mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Volume overload: The patient's diuresis is being driven by lasix, and his volume status is being closely monitored.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and his potassium level is high, indicating acute on chronic renal failure.
3. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is high, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
4. Hepatic congestion: The patient's LFTs are trending down, but his liver function is still compromised.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's heart rhythm is atrial fibrillation, which can lead to complications such as stroke and heart failure.
6. Low EF: The patient's ejection fraction is low, which can lead to decreased cardiac output and increased risk of complications.
7. Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk for stress ulcers due to his critical illness and potential gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. VAP: The patient is at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia due to his mechanical ventilation.

The patient's plan includes continuing lasix drip, monitoring his diuresis and volume status, and trending his creatinine and potassium levels. He will also be monitored for signs of volume overload, renal failure, and hyperkalemia.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with an acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and a history of mitral valve replacement and tricuspid ring. He was transferred from the CCU for ionotrope-assisted diuresis due to persistent hypotension. He is receiving lasix infusion and has a goal of achieving at least 1 L negative fluid balance each day. He also has a diagnosis of LLE cellulitis, acute on chronic renal failure, and transaminitis, which is likely due to hepatic congestion. He is on Coumadin for anticoagulation and has a goal INR of 2.27.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of heart failure: The patient's heart failure may worsen due to ongoing volume overload and poor forward flow, which can lead to further decompensation and increased risk of cardiogenic shock.
2. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may worsen due to continued poor forward flow and volume overload, leading to increased risk of acute kidney injury and further decline in renal function.
3. Infection: The patient's LLE cellulitis may worsen if not properly treated, leading to increased risk of sepsis and organ failure.
4. Bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation therapy with Coumadin may increase his risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of ongoing diuresis and potential gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's slight bibasilar crackles noted on physical examination may indicate early signs of respiratory failure, which can worsen if not addressed promptly.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's ongoing diuresis and potential electrolyte imbalance may lead to further complications, such as hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia.
7. Hepatic failure: The patient's transaminitis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to increased risk of hepatic failure and coagulopathy.
